newsitem.title: GERMANY: Alitalia ups Italy-Korea freight capacity.
newsitem.headline: Alitalia ups Italy-Korea freight capacity.

text.p: Alitalia said it will double capacity to Korea with the launch of two additional Milan-Seoul all-freight flights on September 12.

Alitalia cargo manager Germany, Dirk Steiger, told Reuters in an interview the Italian airline will fly three times weekly non-stop from Milan Malpensa to Seoul in a joint venture with Korean Air Lines.
"The market to Korea is booming. This is primarily Italian market demand for Korea but also export from other European countries," he said.
"The new flights will effectively double capacity to Korea," he added.
The flights, using McDonnell Douglas MD-11F aircraft, will be on Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays and will replace the currently weekly Boeing 747F flight.
A second weekly joint Alitalia-Korean B747F flight using a Korean aircraft had to be dropped in the summer due to a shortage of Korean equipment, he pointed out.
Space on the freighters is likely to be marketed 50:50 by the two airlines but no decision has yet been made on how much will be made available to each European market, Steiger added.
Rates in Italy for the Far East are at a healthy level due to continuing high demand, he noted. - Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+44 171 542 5017
